sect1.title: Manipulating measurements
sect1.para: Naturally, in- and output of measurements is not enough - it is equally important to be able to manipulate them. This can be done using the following methods.

sect2.title: Convert
sect2.para: Probably the most important feature is the conversion into different units of measurement. The conversion of a unit can be done any number of times using the method convertTo().

Units of measurement can only be converted to other units of the same type.
Therefore, it is not possible to convert (e.g.) a length into a weight.

example.title: Convert
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend.php';
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure_Weight');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Locale');

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de');

$mystring = "1.234.567,89";
$unit = new Zend_Measure($mystring,Zend_Measure_Weight::POUND,$locale);

print "Kilo:".$unit->convertTo(Zend_Measure_Weight::KILOGRAM);
print "Ton:".$unit->convertTo(Zend_Measure_Weight::TON);
?>

sect2.title: Add and subtract
sect2.para: Measurements can be added together using add() and subtracted using sub().

example.title: Adding units
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend.php';
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure_Length');

// Define objects
$unit = new Zend_Measure(200,Zend_Measure_Length::CENTIMETER);
$unit2 = new Zend_Measure(1,Zend_Measure_Length::METER);

// Add $unit2 to $unit 
$sum = $unit->add($unit2);

echo $sum;
?>

para.note: Each addition will create a new object for the result.
The new object will be of the same type as the originating object.
Adding one object to another will automatically convert it to the correct unit. It is not neccessary to call convertTo() before adding different units.

example.title: Subtract
example.para: Subtraction of measurements works just like addition.
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend.php';
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure_Length');

// Define objects
$unit = new Zend_Measure(200,Zend_Measure_Length::CENTIMETER);
$unit2 = new Zend_Measure(1,Zend_Measure_Length::METER);

// Subtract $unit2 from $unit
$sum = $unit->sub($unit2);

echo $sum;
?>

sect2.title: Compare
sect2.para: Of course, measurements can also be compared.

example.title: Different measurements
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend.php';
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure_Length');

// Define measurements
$unit = new Zend_Measure(100,Zend_Measure_Length::CENTIMETER);
$unit2 = new Zend_Measure(1,Zend_Measure_Length::METER);

if ($unit->equals($unit2)) {
    print "Both measurements are identical";
} else {
    print "These are different measurements";
}
?>

example.title: Identical measurements
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend.php';
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure_Length');

// Define measurements
$unit = new Zend_Measure(100,Zend_Measure_Length::CENTIMETER);
$unit2 = new Zend_Measure(1,Zend_Measure_Length::METER);

$unit2->setType(Zend_Measure_Length::CENTIMETER);

if ($unit->equals($unit2)) {
    print "Both measurements are identical";
} else {
    print "These are different measurements";
}
?>

para.note: equals() will return TRUE only if both the value and the unit of measure are identical.

sect2.title: Calculate differences
sect2.para: To determine if a measurement is less or greater than another, you can use the compare() method. It will return the difference between two objects as an integer value.
Identical measurements will return 0. Lesser ones will return a negative, greater ones a positive value.

example.title: Difference
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend.php';
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure_Length');

$unit = new Zend_Measure(100,Zend_Measure_Length::CENTIMETER);
$unit2 = new Zend_Measure(1,Zend_Measure_Length::METER);
$unit3 = new Zend_Measure(1.2,Zend_Measure_Length::METER);

print "Equal:".$unit2->compare($unit);
print "Greater:".$unit2->compare($unit3);
print "Lesser:".$unit3->compare($unit2);
?>

sect2.title: Manually change values
sect2.para: Every now and then you might need to change the value of a measurement by hand. This is what the method setValue() is for.
setValue() will overwrite the current value and accepts the same parameters like when creating the object instance.

example.title: Changing a value
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend.php';
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure_Length');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Locale');

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');

$unit = new Zend_Measure(1,Zend_Measure_Length::METER);

$unit->setValue(1.2);
echo $unit;

$unit->setValue(1.2,Zend_Measure_Length::KILOMETER);
echo $unit;

$unit->setValue("1.234,56",Zend_Measure_Length::MILLIMETER,$locale);
echo $unit;
?>

sect2.title: Manually change types
sect2.para: Just like the value, you can also change the type of a measurement without altering its value. This can be done using the method setType().
setType() will not change the current value.

example.title: Changing the type
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend.php';
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure');
Zend::loadClass('Zend_Measure_Length');

$unit = new Zend_Measure(1,Zend_Measure_Length::METER);

// output: 1 m
echo $unit;

// output: 1 km
$unit->setType(Zend_Measure_Length::KILOMETER);
echo $unit;
?>
